instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
Board came in not turning on, had plenty of corrosion from ocean breeze, after a good UC board now turns on and boot fine, but board now has fans running at full speed as soon as power is connected to board, this is with board alone on desk with good IO board and flex.

HWMonitor does not show any problems.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
Missing trackpad will cause this.
SMC is searching for TP thermal sensors...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
With new TP and flex connected same problem, the weird thing is that the fan ramps up to max right away no matter what, I remember that in other cases with a good board the fan ramps up slowly.

<RESISTOR>R4850</RESISTOR>-53 ARE OK
Newly installed <CHIP>U4810</CHIP>
1 = 3.3
2 = 0
3 = 0
4 = 0
5 = 3.3
6 = 0
7 = 0
8 = 3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
Inside macOS, SPI mode is enabled for TP, so pins 5, 6, & 3 MUST all be high.
<CHIP>U4810</CHIP> is AND logic gate and pin 3 has incorrect voltage reported; change it.
Be sure to have good solders and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
New <CHIP>U4810</CHIP> Pin 3 and 6 are still 0V with or without TP connected, this is now 3 <CHIP>U4810</CHIP> important to note that area around <CHIP>U4810</CHIP> is clean

<RESISTOR>R4850</RESISTOR>-53 and <RESISTOR>R1630</RESISTOR> ARE OK
Newly installed <CHIP>U4810</CHIP>
1 = 3.3
2 = 3.3
3 = 0
4 = 0
5 = 3.3
6 = 0
7 = 3.3
8 = 3.3

Sorry for posting wrong info at first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message: Looked clean, but replaced them regardless and still same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
Possibly corrosion under TP connector.
Also reball SMC, as usual for liquid damaged boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
Reballed SMC and removed TP connector same problem.

I mentioned this before but I will mention it again, normal behavior with the same exact board in working order is that the fan starts slow and as it notices that the TP is missing or damaged the fan ramps up to max speed, this board here as soon as I connect the power cable to it the fan goes to max right away, I hope that helps with solving the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan at full speed right at the start
threads.message:
Fan spining to max from moment zero is normal starting in SMC bypass mode.
But the board shouldn't start in such mode by itself.

Check <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> and its adjacent resistors and traces.
You should change SMC, as it controls the fan.
